article:
{{Infobox saint |name=Jerome |birth_date=c. 347 |death_date=420 |feast_day=30
September (Western Christianity) 15 June (Eastern Christianity)
|venerated_in=Roman Catholic Church Eastern Orthodoxy Anglican
Communion Lutheranism Oriental Orthodoxy |image=St.-Jerome-In-His-
Study.jpg |imagesize=280px |caption=Saint Jerome visited by angels by Bartolomeo
Cavarozzi |birth_place=Stridon (possibly Strido Dalmatiae, on the border of
Dalmatia and Pannonia) |death_place=Bethlehem, Palaestina Prima |titles=Doctor
of the Church |attributes=lion, cardinal attire, cross, skull, trumpet, owl,

|major_shrine=Basilica of Saint Mary Major, Rome, Italy |suppressed_date=
|major_works=[[The Vulgate]] [[De viris illustribus]] [[Chronicon
(Jerome)|Chronicon]] |prayer=O Lord, show your mercy to me and gladden my heart.
I am like the man on the way to Jericho who was overtaken by robbers, wounded
and left for dead. O Good Samaritan, come to my aid, I am like the sheep that
went astray. O Good Shepherd, seek me out and bring me home in accord with your
will. Let me dwell in your house all the days of my life and praise you for ever
and ever with those who are there. |prayer_attrib=Saint Jerome }}

'Saint Jerome' (Latin: 'Eusebius Sophronius Hieronymus'; ; c. 347 â 30 September
420) was a Latin Christian priest, confessor, theologian and historian, who also
became a Doctor of the Church. He was the son of Eusebius, of the city of
Stridon, on the border of Dalmatia and Pannonia. He is best known for his
translation of the Bible into Latin (the Vulgate), and his commentaries on the
Gospel of the Hebrews. His list of writings is extensive.

He is recognised as a saint by the Catholic Church, the Eastern Orthodox Church,
the Lutheran Church, and the Church of England (Anglican Communion). In the
Eastern Orthodox Church he is known as St. Jerome of Stridonium or Blessed
Jerome. Though "Blessed" in this context does not have the sense of being less
than a saint, as in the West. Jerome is commemorated on 30 September with
a memorial.
categories: Translators of the Bible into Latin
